templates.content:
Great question! So the 28mm size is ideal for precision on small cutting jobs - it can cut into inside corners on intricate appliques with better control than a larger blade, and is also ideal for cutting clothing pattern pieces with curved lines like armscyes and notches. 

For the 45mm size, choose that when you have small straight cuts to do, like cutting on the line for half square triangles. It's also the one to choose if you only have one rotary cutter as it does most cutting jobs well. As for the largest 60mm size, it's great for those who have larger hands, and is good for cutting up to six layers of quilting cotton or for long straight cuts like the width of fabric folded.
templates.name: Difference between the Rotary Cutters

templates.content: It's made of plastic!
templates.name: What are the pegboards made of?

templates.content:
Sure thing! The dimension of each individual pegboard is 11inchx11inches (about 28x28cm) and each starter set comes with four pegboards. The hardware or accessories included are:
 
2 Long boxes (28x9x3cm)
2 Transparent storage boxes with lid (10x8x8cm)
1 Square storage box (7.5x9x8cm)
1 Set of three (3) C-sized hooks (4.5x7cm)
1 Set of two (2) clips (2x8cm)
templates.name: Can you give me more information on the pegboards?

templates.content: The presser foot set comes with an impressive set of instructions, and you'll find a booklet with descriptions of all the feet in the set. On page 3 of that booklet, you'll find the instructions on how to access the digital manual with more elaborate user instructions and tutorial videos, including a printable version of the manual!
